Odio las mecánicas (mención especial para el conio de los disquitos de influencia), lo desequilibrado que es todo en cuanto a losetas de sector o losetas de descubrimiento, lo demencial que es poder gestionar los recursos como uno quiere, la arbitrariedad de las tecnologías y lo aplastantemente decisivo que puede ser el orden de turno para ese aspecto....

En cuanto pierdas un par de sectores y produzcas una birria de todo, no remontas ni harto de vino.

No sé, no le he visto la gracia en ningún momento.

EDITO: dice un compañero de la partida que leyó aquí en BGG que Eclipse es bastante como tratar de lidiar con una mano de cartas que se te da al principio, de tratar de hacerlo lo mejor posible con esas cartas; puede ser, pero para mí que le faltan mecanismos para lidiar con los déficits que uno pueda tener, o las ventajas (brutales) que otros jugadores puedan sacar simplemente a través de la exploración.

Ejemplos: mientras entre mis sectores apenas había 2 planetas marrones, otros no sólo producían a tope, sino que se encontraron así como con 12 recursos de material en 2 exploraciones; no sólo eso, además, así como quien no quiere la cosa, con un anillo orbital GRA-TIS; o sea, mientras uno (yo) tuvo que investigar la correspondiente tecnología, y construirlos (construí dos), otro obtuvo uno por el morro, sin hacer nada... no lo veo normal; pero es que otro compañero obtuvo dos PIEZAS (no tecnologías, no: piezas directamente) muy buenas, y que directamente pudo añadir a sus naves así como si nada; mientras tanto, los demás nos las veíamos y deseábamos para investigar las tecnologías de armamento correspondientes, e incorporarlas a sus naves

Porque esa es otra (e importante): obtener mediante la exploración una pieza de nave súper chetada te permite con una sola acción (explorar) lo que a otros les cuesta a lo mejor esperar una ronda (para tener ciencia suficiente y poder investigar), y mínimo dos acciones (investigar y mejorar la nave); igual que lo del anillo orbital "encontrado", que es aún peor: te ahorras dos acciones (investigar, construir) y además el material...

Pero es que el desnivel entre las losetas que a unos y a otros les salían, fue tremendo.

Por no hablar del descacharrante sistema de la bolsa de fichas de reputación/puntos cuando se resuelve un combate: resulta que en uno que gané en el que aplasté a mi rival y saqué 5 fichas... ¡las 5 eran de 1 punto! "Es que ya se ha ido combatiendo y sacando las fichas buenas", me decían. Que no entendía eso, me decían. Claro que lo entiendo, pero me parece un sistema mierder, qué queréis que os diga.

El manejo de los recursos, de los discos de influencia y demás, me parece también un dolor de cabeza innecesario, no sé. Dependes de lo que te salga, vale. ¡Pero es que no hay forma de paliarlo!

Y el sistema de losetas de tecnología, y no poder investigar más que lo que hay disponible, me parece otro elemento demencial: en la primera ronda salieron dos losetas de la dichosa bomba de neutrones. ¿Qué pasa? Que de los tres primeros, dos pillaron esa tecnología. ¿Que tú no la puedes investigar? Ah, pues te jo...s. Es la importancia del orden de turno... Ya, pero es que era la primera ronda, dime tú dónde está la gracia 

Otro detalle: para producir algo más de material, intercambié embajadores con mis dos vecinos, muy bien; pero en cuanto me atacaron, pam, como hay que devolverlos, iba a volver a producir poquísimo material.

Y otro: no me gusta nada la mecánica del movimiento, que tus naves se queden bloqueadas simplemente porque haya otras de otro jugador (no dan alternativa salvo pegarse), y que las batallas sean hasta que quede uno en pie... ¡con lo que cuesta construir cualquier nave un poco decente! Salvo que te encuentres una de chiripa, claro, que también les ocurrió a otros compañeros, mira qué bien 

En fin, donde se ponga un Clash of Cultures...

A lot of promise, here. I love-love-love the idea of upgradeable ship blueprints, it's a lot more fine-grained than I see in other 4X games, except maybe Space Empires 4X.

I also like that the economics matter, a lot, and you have this push-pull between doing more in early phases vs saving for later actions later in the game.

But, there's very little to push players into fighting OR negotiating with each other. TI has a whole phase of the game solely for arguing with the other players, which I really appreciate, and Dune has all kinds of backstab-y negotiations laced throughout the game. Eclipse winds up feeling a lot more like wingspan (it is basically an engine builder at heart, with a space-empire theme) and a lot less like a political negotiation game like TI or Dune.

Another thing I really missed was background lore. Dune obviously has an enormous leg up here, but even TI has some very clearly communicated tropes behind each faction. These dudes are super into trading, those weirdos are all about backstabby fascism, this group of fish are super good at research and getting advanced technology. Nobody will say that the lore of TI is sublime fiction reading, but almost every component is pulling you into the story of the game, what's happened in the past, what is currently playing out on the board. Even if it's mostly trope-heavy, but it gives players a ton of hooks to grab onto to turn "hey, can you move your dreadnaught to this hex" into "The Emirates of Hacan formally request you to assist our resistance of the occupation of our sovereign territory at Quann."

It isn't going to win a Hugo, but damn if it doesn't make the games feel 100 times richer and more alive.

Weird beast of a game, is my impression after a gladly abandoned half-finished game. So many neat rules that serve to replicate the feeling of playing a computer game space 4x, a genre I love. However, it misses out on a crucial aspect of the computer games: being able to just reload if you are randomly put in the worst place in the galaxy. Here, you'd have to suffer through the game, seeing how you lag behind, for 3-6 hours. Compared to this input randomness at the beginning, accepting the chance of the combat dice is no problem.

Still, it must be nice to be the player who lucked out at the beggining, and be able to build up a nice empire, so I'd be temped to try it again.

If I owned the game, I'd either sell it immediately, or try to house-rule the setup (probably by stacking the balance of the 3rd level exploration tiles before a game, making sure good and bad tiles are somehow distributed evenly around the table, or by adding some cost to the really exterme exploration-technology tiles, whatever they are called). This way, I'm just glad someone tought it, and I experienced enough of it to loose the urge to ever wanting to buy it.

Eclipse was one my favorite games in 2012. This second edition seems like a general improvement on things, although maybe it doesn't totally resolve the situation where one player can luck into incredibly powerful cannon blueprints early on and throw off the balance. The great innovation of this game was that it was like a 4x game and euro game combination, which in 2012 felt really revolutionary. At this point, I think I'd lean more towards Scythe for that feeling. Again, this isn't bad, I'm just a very different gamer now than I was in 2012 when this would have been a knock out of the park.

Before the dice even hit the table, the exploration phase already feels like RNGesus is targeting me personally. One unlucky event and my whole game turns into a solo tragedy while everyone else is having a blast!

A lot of interesting and fun mechanics going on here with an incredible production value- itt feels on the precipice of something incredible, but the premise falls short largely due to RNG.

It wouldn't be so bad if it were a shorter game, but if you have bad luck in the beginning with your exploration tiles you simply slog through hours of unexciting gameplay just crawling along with minimal payoff while your friends get to have all the fun and optimize their fleet.

Exploration is random, combat dice randomness (yes, there's programming, but if you get a bad roll or a really good one you can still swing the favour of the game, as losing is quite punishing), upgrade selection randomness (no guarantees of what you will be able to build in the future and if it works with your goals), reward tiles are random (again back to exploration, really).

You could try to argue it's more of a tactile than a strategic game, but even then the heaviness of the random factors can remove even your tactile response options.

A bit too much luck for my liking, and if I wanted an area control game determined by luck I would ultimately play something much shorter.

A decade ago, I owned, played several times, and traded away a copy of Eclipse (1st ed). There were things that I really liked about the game at the time. I really liked how costs and benefits were tracked by revealing new numbers similar to Through the Ages. Building your own ship blueprints was fantastic. The tech tree was streamlined into a series of logical discounts that let you jump ahead at a cost or progress naturally. The different factions offered a wide variety of play styles, including the human factions, which weren't just dismissed as the "vanilla" choice but had actual advantages over the more alien factions. I'm pleased to say that all of these things that I liked about the first edition are preserved or improved on in Second Dawn.

Unfortunately, the issues that I had with the first edition that caused me to trade it away persisted in Second Dawn. First, the absolute swing in different map and discovery tiles is absurdly broad. I enjoy randomness in games, but usually randomness has a chance to flatten out so that no single player is overly advantaged. I've never found this to be the case in Eclipse. While Second Dawn improves exploration by not requiring an influence tile to be placed to claim the discovery tiles, that doesn't change the wide imbalance in what the map tile will offer (especially in terms of Ancients) and separately what the discovery tiles have to offer. I understand that eXploration is a critical part of the 4X formula, but this aspect of Eclipse has always felt underdeveloped to me.

Second, I've never been a fan of combat systems that are fulled open-ended in terms of when the combat ends. I like combat that runs through one round of dice rolling, like Nexus Ops or one round of card drawing like Warrior Knights or Runewars. Combat that continues without guarantee of progress or change of game state for round upon round like in Eclipse or Twilight Imperium really doesn't sit well with me. This is definitely a bittersweet pill with Eclipse, because the combat also relies so much on those blueprints that are so fun to create.

I'm not against playing again, but this still isn't a game I would readily seek out still, especially with so many other 3X/4X games I've had more fun with.
